repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Fourth Small and Medium
            Industries Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Fourth Small and
            Medium Industries Project for Sri Lanka was satisfactory.
            The project achieved its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was substantial, sustainability is
            likely, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, financial viability and internal efficiency
            of the participating financial institutions is the most
            important factor in the satisfactory implementation of the
            intermediation operations and sustainability of the project.
            Second, an effective and strong Apex institution is
            important and instrumental for successful project
            implementation. Third, Government direct involvement in and
            thorough knowledge of all aspects of the project is crucial
            for better coordination among stakeholders. Fourth, it would
            be beneficial to invest in upgrading the database and
            monitoring system for the SMI sector. Fifth, the TA program
            and its goals/objectives should be realistic and achievable.
            Finally, the experience of severe power cuts and its impact
            on the economy calls for an urgent need to develop the Sri
            Lanka's infrastructures.

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - World Bank Support for Small
            and Medium Industries in Sri Lanka : the First, Second,
            Third, and Fourth Small and Medium Industries Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The World Bank Support for Small and
            Medium Industries (SMI) in Sri Lanka was achieved. In sum,
            the impact of the Bank has been satisfactory. Given these
            results, the projects' outcomes should be seen in a
            more positive light than that presented by the audit for the
            first two credits, which rated them as unsatisfactory. Slow,
            but ultimately realized, policy reforms and subsequent
            projects addressed the weaknesses of the earlier projects.
            These projects also had satisfactory outcomes. Indeed, they
            laid the groundwork for a very fruitful policy discussion
            that continues today. Their sustainability is likely and
            their institutional development is strong. The major lessons
            of these projects are three. First, the sharp decline in
            Bank support for SMI projects in recent years may have been
            a missed opportunity. From the review of these projects it
            is clear that if correctly structured, SMI operations can be
            effective employment programs. Second, the resolution of the
            most important problems confronting SMI's in Sri Lanka
            requires broader financial sector reforms, rather than just
            more credit, as was emphasized in the last project. However,
            broader international experience suggests that Sri
            Lanka's slowness in fully realizing these reforms is
            not unusual. Finally, international experience also suggests
            that greater fiscal discipline than has been achieved in Sri
            Lanka may be a necessary condition for financial reforms to
            be sustainable.

Sri Lanka - World Bank Support for Small and

            and Fourth Small and Medium Industries Projects

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Fourth Small and Medium
            Industries (SMI IV) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Fourth Small and
            Medium Industries Project, which complement previous and
            ongoing industrial and financial sector intermediation
            operations, are to: (a) make a further contribution to
            policy reform and institutional strengthening in the areas
            of trade policy administration and financial sector
            operations; and (b) provide credit through the banking
            system for long term, capital investment in eligible
            productive enterprises. Major elements of the project will
            be a credit component, onlent by the National Development
            Bank (NDB) to Participating Credit Institutions (PCI) for
            financing private sector capital investments; and a
            technical assistance component to fund: (a) project
            implementation support; (b) institutional development; and
            (c) policy and procedural development, particularly in the
            area of environmental management.

docna.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Fourth Small and Medium
            Industries (SMI IV) Project
